Award.AwardTitle: Tribal College STEM History Documentation Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
The purpose of the Tribal College STEM History Documentation Project is to investigate the growth and development of the tribal college movement. This study will be the first attempt to place the history of the tribal college movement in a larger policy context. Rather than viewing the colleges as exceptional institutions working apart from the mainstream of society, it will explore the relationship between tribal institutions and the larger educational and policy community. This approach allows for a more nuanced understanding of the factors that strengthened the colleges and the challenges faced by both tribal colleges and mainstream agencies in the formation of these relationships. Through its case study approach, it will also provide a better understanding of the National Science Foundation's unique role in the development of the tribal college movement.

Broader Impacts
This study will significantly expand the existing scholarship of the tribal college movement and highlight factors that contribute to the successful implementation of competitive STEM instructional programs. Findings will provide a deeper understanding of barriers faced by institutions that work outside of the educational mainstream and the opportunities and challenges faced by agencies that choose to support their work.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tribal colleges are institutions of higher learning created by Native Americans, controlled by Indian tribes, and located on or near reservations. First established in the late 1960s and early 1970s, they represent a unique part of American higher education. However, the movement's origins are poorly documented; until recently, many institutional histories were maintained only through the stories told by founders. Yet even this knowledge was being lost as long-serving presidents and administrators retired or passed away. The Tribal College History Documentation Project represented a significant opportunity to record and preserve experiences of American Indians who envisioned and developed some of the oldest tribal colleges before their knowledge was lost.

The grant support two key activities. First, videotaped interviews were conducted with longstanding leaders within the tribal college movement during 2013 and audiotaped interviews, primarily conducted in 1996, were professionally transferred to archival quality CDs for future use by scholars and distribution to tribal colleges. Secondly, a 128-page monograph examining the history of the tribal college movement, based on the video and audiotapped interviews, was completed and published in the fall of 2015 by Salish Kootenai College Press and distributed by the University of Nebraska Press.

This project is the first comprehensive effort to record and disseminate oral histories of early tribal college leaders. It is expected that these materials will serve as a resource for scholars examining the history of American Indian education, as well as current leaders within the tribal college movement who often know little about the origins of the colleges they run.

In addition, the documents also serve as a resource for policy makers working to shape effective educational policy. A key finding of the project is that tribal colleges are, in part, a response to 1960s-era  "self help" community development initiatives. In recent decades, these efforts have been forgotten by political leaders, or viewed as failures. However, the survival and growth of tribal colleges suggests that these programs did make a difference and might justify a reevaluation of some War on Poverty initiatives, including policies that promote greater local autonomy in economic development and educational policy.
